Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Geometrical and Statistical Modeling of Space-Time symmetries for Human Action Analysis and Retraining

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This interdisciplinary research aims to advance current understanding and utilization of space-time symmetries in analyzing human movements, using fundamental tools from engineering, geometry, and statistics. Broader applications of this research include home or workplace-based self-reflection of daily activities, promotion of higher efficiency of human movements, and long-term management and/or prevention of movement disorders. While the need for comprehensively and statistically analyzing human kinematics is well chronicled, the current measures are often limited to simplistic quantities such as speeds and acceleration profiles of individual limbs. This project will focus on both spatial and temporal symmetries of limb movements, full body shapes, and complete dynamical actions, for assessment of movements ranging from daily activities to physiotherapeutic exercises.

Symmetry has been used in the past, in clinical biomechanics, but in a limited way. This project will develop a comprehensive theory, built on fundamental tools from differential geometry and statistical analysis of geometric objects, to represent, quantify, analyze, and classify motions according to their level of symmetry. The specific forms of symmetry will include spatial reflection, temporal reflection, and space-time glide symmetries. This formulation will incorporate data from various sensing modalities and features, including point trajectories and stick figures from motion capture systems, to shape silhouettes and dynamic textures obtained from video sensors. The project outcomes also include the development of a real-time media-system for movement re-training and reflection of common actions, such as sitting to standing (STS). The proposal brings together a strong and inter-disciplinary team of researchers with expertise in computer vision and action recognition (Turaga), differential geometry and statistics (Srivastava), and somatics and kinesiology (Coleman).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on development of geometric representations and statistical methodologies for use in analyzing human actions and activities from remote-sensing or body-centric devices. The broad goals of this research were to: (1) mathematically represent articulations of human bodies using non-Euclidean shape representations and impose statistical models on those representations, (2) exploit symmetries in spatial-temporal patterns of shapes formed by human motions to analyze actions and activities, and (3) apply these tools to analyze human activity data for vocational, medical, or other evaluation purposes.

The main accomplishments of this project are:

  • Derivation of mathematical theory for analyzing human articulations as trajectories on nonlinear Riemannian manifolds.  
  • Development of statistical modeling and machine learning tools adapted to these representation manifolds.
  • Demonstration of these methods to analysis of remotely sensed and/or body-centric motion data, especially for analyzing kinematics and medical evaluations.
  • Broader applications of these statistical shape analysis theory in applications from biology, brain anatomy, and COVID-19 epidemiology.

 

The specific solutions developed under this project include:

  1. Defining prototypical human movements, quantifications of deviations from these prototypes, and statistical testing of human motions for subjects sampled from different populations. 
  2. Techniques for separating motion from execution rate and using these two time-series for analyzing human activities in the context of manufacturing and operations research. 
  3. Quantification, clustering and prototyping of shapes and shape evolutions of biological objects such botanical trees, biological cells, mitochondria, protein, and 3D chromosomes. 
  4. Clustering and classification of COVID-19 rate curves for different geographical regions (e.g. different US states or counties) according to their shapes. This helps understand and highlight spatial heterogeneity in COVID occurrences across large regions. 

This research was broadly disseminated. It directly resulted in at least 10 research articles in high-quality, peer-reviewed journals and was additionally presented at a number of international conferences. The PIs also organized three international workshops on the topic areas of this research.

This project either partially or fully supported four PhD students in their dissertation research, training them in areas involving machine learning, geometry, statistics, and computational science. These students found jobs in academia and industry after graduation. This research also helped strengthen or develop several research collaborations outside our university.
